reasoning:
First off, Netflix sits well outside my circle of competence. I understand consumer staples, insurance and railroads, but a constantly evolving streaming business with huge content spend and fickle subscriber tastes isn’t one of them. It’s like trying to pick a winner in a horse race when you’ve never been to the track.

Its moat is unproven. Sure, Netflix has a large subscriber base and decent operating margins (roughly 29%), but a durable competitive advantage? I don’t see one. Its ROE is a meager 2.1% over the latest period and only once in ten years did it exceed 15%—hardly what you’d call a fortress. Competitors like Disney+ and Amazon are muscling in, and content costs keep ratcheting up.

On management and capital allocation, I’ll give them credit for not flooding the market with new shares and for generating around $9 billion in owner earnings. But they’ve leaned heavily on debt—over four times equity—and are locked in an arms race for content. No dividend, no buybacks—your capital sits there while they reinvest aggressively in a business that hasn’t shown consistent returns.

Financially you get strong operating margins, but a weak balance sheet and spotty earnings consistency. They grew total earnings 176% over ten periods, yet the pattern was all over the map. You don’t want a roller coaster when you’re planning to hold forever.

Valuation is the final nail. A three-stage DCF pegs conservative intrinsic value at about $136 a share. Netflix trades well above that, leaving you no margin of safety—in fact, you’re basically paying twice what I think the business is worth.

Long term, streaming will matter, but the business model demands endless cash burn and content bets that may or may not pay off. That’s not the kind of predictable, margin-rich, capital-light franchise I look for.

Compared to owning Coca-Cola at 20 times earnings or Berkshire’s insurance float, Netflix feels riskier and far more expensive. I’d pass on it.

fundamental_analysis.details: Weak ROE of 2.1%; High debt to equity ratio of 4.3; Strong operating margins; Current ratio data not available

consistency_analysis.details: Inconsistent earnings growth pattern; Total earnings growth of 176.8% over past 10 periods

moat_analysis.details: Inconsistent ROE: only 0/10 periods >15%; Decent operating margins (avg: 31.5%) suggest some competitive advantage

book_value_analysis.details: Consistent book value per share growth (Buffett's favorite metric)

management_analysis.details: No significant new stock issuance detected; No or minimal dividends paid

details: Using three-stage DCF: Stage 1 (8.0%, 5y), Stage 2 (4.0%, 5y), Terminal (2.5%)
